xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9" xmlns:ns2="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9 http://www.loc.gov/ead/ead.xsd">mss_593Guide to the Dixon Place Archived Websites MSS.593Collection processed by Nicole GreenhouseFales Library and Special CollectionsThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2022-01-24T21:00:37January 2022
Edited by Nicole Greenhouse to add additional archived websites and updated administrative information Materials are in English.
Fales Library and Special Collections
Dixon Place Archived Websites
Dixon Place
MSS.593
7 websites in 7 archived websites.
November 2017-ongoing Dixon Place is an experimental nonprofit theater located on Chrystie Street in New York that supports original theater, puppetry, dance, music, and circus arts. The collection contains their website and calendar, with captures of the website dating back to 2017.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.
Accruals
New site crawls are accrued monthly. Youtube channel is accrued semiannually.
Appraisal
Crawl was limited to domains and subdomains of tickets.vendini.com and dixonplace.org in order to remain within the collection scope and data constraints.
Robots.txt (a piece of code designed to limit crawler activity within a website) was ignored.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Dixon Place Archived Websites; MSS 593; Wayback URL; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.
Take Down Policy
Archived websites are made accessible for purposes of education and research. NYU Libraries have given attribution to rights holders when possible; however, due to the nature of archival collections, we are not always able to identify this information.
If you hold the rights to materials in our archived websites that are unattributed, please let us know so that we may maintain accurate information about these materials.
If you are a rights holder and are concerned that you have found material on this website for which you have not granted permission (or is not covered by a copyright exception under US copyright laws), you may request the removal of the material from our site by submitting a notice, with the elements described below, to the special.collections@nyu.edu.
Please include the following in your notice: Identification of the material that you believe to be infringing and information sufficient to permit us to locate the material; your contact information, such as an address, telephone number, and email address; a statement that you are the owner, or authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed and that you have a good-faith belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; a statement that the information in the notification is accurate and made under penalty of perjury; and your physical or electronic signature. Upon receiving a notice that includes the details listed above, we will remove the allegedly infringing material from public view while we assess the issues identified in your notice.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
http://dixonplace.org/ and https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/171/ were selected by curators and captured through the use of Archive-It in 2017. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website. In June 2019, https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/171/ redirected to https://red.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?t=tix&w=5eb083aed80d8417b6339a1159294ebe and was added to the web archive. The accession number associated with this website is 2019.068. In September 2019, https://red.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?t=tix&w=5eb083aed80d8417b6339a1159294ebe redirected to https://tickets.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?t=tix&w=5eb083aed80d8417b6339a1159294ebe&vqitq=3609ad7e-edcc-40c2-ae84-cd2b90bdda24&vqitp=cd496099-9898-495c-b943-879ffc9e72bd&vqitts=1570026703&vqitc=vendini&vqite=itl&vqitrt=Safetynet&vqith=869990f73ecc6bc117af3b9c410f8ee9. The accession number associated with this website is 2019.076. In 2020, https://www.youtube.com/user/dixonplacevideos/videos was added. The accession number associated with this website is 2021.004.
In December 2020, https://sites.google.com/view/blackbladeatdp/home was added. The accession number associated with this website is 2021.028. In June 2021, https://ci.ovationtix.com/35526/ was added. The accession number associated with this website is 2022.003.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were captured.
Processing Information
The finding aid for the archived websites was created in 2019. In 2021, the Youtube channel and BlackBlade radio play were added to the finding aid. In 2021-2022, the calendar page redirected and was added to the finding aid.
Scope and Contents
The Dixon Place website features information about upcoming events, the theater board, the theater's restaurant and lounge, membership, and space rental. Events are broken down into categories, such as theater, in the lounge, film, dance, gallery, music, literature, variety arts, and puppetry. Each event contains a synopsis of the show and biographical information on the artists. The website also provides information on their resident artists; performance, literary, and dance series; their annual Hot! festival; the Tom Murrin Performance Award; and their cultural and community outreach programs to seniors and youth. In 2020, the Youtube channel was added to capture contents related to Dixon Place's virtual activities during the COVID-19 pandemic. It also includes a radio play called BlackBlade. BlackBlade is a 4 part radio play presented by Dixon Place as part of the Titan Cycle.
Historical Note
Dixon Place is an experimental nonprofit theater in New York that supports original theater, puppetry, dance, music, and circus arts. It was first conceived in 1985 in the Paris apartment of artistic director Ellie Covan. In 1986, Covan began the theater in her East First Street apartment with a weekly reading series called "Tuesdays at Dixon Place." In 1991, Dixon Place moved to a location on the Bowery and in 1999 became the resident company at Vineyard Theater. Dixon Place served as an incubator for artists such as Deb Margolin, Blue Man Group, John Leguizamo, Lisa Kron, David Cale, Penny Arcade, and Reno. In 2009, Dixon Place moved into its permanent home on Chrystie Street. The space consists of a 150 person theater, lounge, and bar.
Performing arts -- Production and direction. Theater -- New York (N.Y.) Web sites.
